Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to David Mitchell is "A Genome-wide Investigation of Light Intensity Effects on the Maize RNA Structurome". The host institution for the fellowship is the Pennsylvania State University and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. Philip C. Bevilacqua and Dr. Sarah M. Assmann.

As maize is a vital food and fuel crop, efforts have been made to increase maize yields by increasing planting density. Dense planting increases the canopy cover and blocks sunlight from reaching the lower leaves, thus stimulating shade avoidance responses which limits crop yield. Information obtained from this research can contribute to genetic engineering of maize to improve yield under high planting densities. Powerful tools used and developed in this research will revolutionize how RNA structure and function are studied. Through this project, the researcher will gain novel expertise in plant biology techniques and in computational and bioinformatics analysis. Furthermore, for six weeks annually underrepresented high school students will be mentored in laboratory research projects.

This research will adapt Structure-seq to maize to perform high-throughput, genome-wide in vivo investigation of gene expression, RNA secondary structures, and RNA-protein interactions in response to low-light stress. By applying new structure-probing chemical reagents that allow Structure-seq to probe all four RNA bases, this research will better enable Structure-seq to distinguish RNA-RNA from RNA-protein interactions. It will examine the use of in vivo crosslinking via photoactivatable nucleoside analogues to provide direct proximity information on these interactions. Furthermore, it will modify the Structure-seq RNA structure prediction algorithm to incorporate constraints from proximity information, sequence complementarity, and known protein binding motifs. Data generated from this research will be uploaded upon processing to the appropriate community databases, including the NCBI Sequence Reads archive (SRA) for RNA structure data (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra) and GEO for RNA-seq data (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo).

POR.DRECONTENT:
My NSF postdoctoral fellowship allowed me to improve techniques for studying RNA structure, particularly within plants. I also used my fellowship tenure to mentor and inspire minority undergraduate students to pursue scientific research.

Among multiple other cellular functions, RNA acts as an intermediary in the expression of genetic information from genes encoded in DNA to their output as proteins. However, gene expression relies not only upon which RNAs are made but how these RNA molecules fold upon themselves. Folding of RNA?RNA structure?can allow or deny access to the RNA by ribosomes, the molecular machinery that produces proteins. Furthermore, RNA structure influences its own production from DNA, a process called transcription. RNA folding during transcription can determine if a complete RNA molecule is made or if transcription halts prematurely. As a result, gaining better understanding of RNA folding, particularly under different biological contexts, allows researchers to better understand gene expression in these contexts.

Many existing methods to study RNA structure employ chemical reagents that react with regions of the RNA that are highly flexible and not obscured by interactions with other RNA regions or proteins (Figure 1a). The enzyme reverse transcriptase, which uses RNA as a template to produce cDNA, then is used to read out locations of reagent reactivity, either by causing enzyme stops and truncated cDNA (Figure 1b, top) or mutations within cDNA (Figure 1b, bottom). Sequencing of the cDNAs provides information about where on the RNA the reagents reacted, and this information subsequently is fed into special software to create structure model predictions of the RNA.

For methods that directly investigate interactions between RNA bases, the reagent dimethyl sulfate (DMS) is widely used (Figure 2). However, DMS only usefully reacts with two of the four bases (A and C), giving no information on the other two bases (G and U). The lack of information on G and U bases potentially compromises accurate structure prediction. Furthermore, while reagents currently exist that can react with these two RNA bases, these reagents cannot cross cell walls and membranes to enter a living cell in the way DMS can. This is important because the cellular, or in vivo, environment differs greatly from buffers used in test tubes (an in vitro environment) typically used to study RNAs. Thus, the RNA structures measured using in vitro techniques may not reflect cellular structures.

I developed two reagents suitable for investigating in vivo RNA structure, glyoxal and EDC (Figure 2). I found that glyoxal primarily reacts with the RNA base G and also to a smaller extent with A and C, providing in vivo structural information for a once previously unavailable base. Variants of glyoxal with hydrophobic modifications, methylglyoxal and phenylglyoxal, react more readily with RNA. Glyoxal reagents successfully reacted with RNAs within rice seedlings and in two different bacterial species, demonstrating the capability of glyoxal to work within cells of multiple domains of life. However, glyoxal alone could not resolve the information gap as it provided no information on U bases. My subsequent research with EDC provided a reagent that could enter cells and react with U and G bases. Similar to glyoxal, EDC works within multiple domains of life, including plants and bacteria. Importantly, I employed EDC to probe RNA structure within maize, a vital crop plant but one previously unstudied in such a manner.

Now capable of probing all four RNA bases, I employed DMS and EDC to investigate potential effects of RNA structure on biological responses maize employs to avoid shade and seek sunlight. While complete outcomes remain pending for this project, I developed a method of affordably targeting multiple RNAs that reacted with the aforementioned reagents and isolating them for further study. Here, I took advantage of the existing maize genome to generate short DNA probes that perfectly paired with portions of the desired RNAs. These DNAs contain biotin, which through its strong interaction with streptavidin allow me to extract the specific RNAs while leaving behind untargeted RNAs. Compared to existing methods, this method creates probes to isolate thirty RNA molecules for $1000, formerly the cost for isolating one.

During my tenure under the fellowship, I participated in Penn State?s Millennium Scholars program. This summertime program provides a six-week course covering many subjects to minority students entering their freshman year. These students, upon finishing the program, survive the rigors of college classes far better, which allows them a greater opportunity for graduation and obtaining success beyond college. I, along with other graduate students within the Bevilacqua lab, taught introductory chemistry lessons. I also directly mentored a minority undergraduate student within the Bevilacqua lab, helping her complete her own research project. As a minority myself, my mentorship helps to provide a positive example for these students and shows that science is a viable path for them.
